There were also some small issues that were inconvenient. For example, we weren’t provided with the WiFi network name and there were many potential options. Combine that with the fact that the WiFi password printed on the sheet was not the same as the one on the fridge and we had to spend a bit finding the right combo.
There was food left in the fridge, but there was no indication if it was meant for us to use, if it belonged to the host or if had been left by previous guests.
This place has potential. It’s spacious and has a nice backyard. With some minor improvements it would be really nice. However, when I compare it to other Airbnbs I’ve stayed in, it just doesn’t measure up.

James’ gracious home was a wonderful oasis to stay in after a long day on the road. It felt a bit like entering another era — immersing ourselves in all the cool details of a full and well-lived existence. We loved the antiques, the old books, the many idiosyncratic parts of a century-old house full of nooks and unique features. Our girls explored all the parts and then holed up in their favorite bedroom together. The beds were so comfortable, the shower delightful, the towels thick. We enjoyed having take-out at the beautiful dining room table and admired the well-stocked modern kitchen with all the amenities. I wished we could have stayed another couple of days just to soak it all in (or get to cook in the fabulous kitchen!). Unlike some other AirBnb’s, which are cute but not really lived in, this house has *amazing* personality and a fascinating long story to tell.
For those visitors who like to run, we thought the nearby neighborhood was also interesting, near enough to a creek trail for a good longish jog. In the morning we got to drive through Texarkana’s charming downtown and then had coffee and danishes at Brewster’s. We hope to be back!!
Thank you, James, for your lovely hospitality.
